You choose to keep the sword, pay 1 pt to the cannon corner, pay 1 pt to the trumpet corner and re-roll.) As long as you don't win, you can continue to pay 1 point to the appropriate corner(s) for each die re-rolled. Once you have three of the same betting item, take all chips on that item and your turn is over. For each treasure chest rolled, every player (including you) puts 1 point on the treasure chest. You can stop rolling and pass at any time. A player who runs out of chips is out of the game.

name: Starters
description:
From the publisher:

What do LRU, XCI, NFD all have in common? They are all possible letter combinations you may be asked to make a larger word from while playing starters. First, all players draw their three "starters" letters. Now you have one frantic minute to write down the shortest word you can think of that contains three letters somewhere in the word.
Sound easy? Well, the letters must appear in the same order in the word as they were drawn and the word must be a minimum four letters long. After you've thought of your word there may still be some time left to gain points from other players by forming words using their letters. When time is up, everyone compares their words and the player having the shortest word for each group of "starters" earns points for it.
publishers: Friends of Friends Fun Factory, Northern Games Co. Ltd.

name: Galapagos
description:
A magazine game from Jeux et Stratégie #22

Players try to bring as many baby turtles from their mothers to the sea while avoiding killer birds.

name: Cortège officiel
description:
A magazine game from Jeux et Stratégie #24.

The police player is trying to get the President to the airport, the protester player is trying to block him. The terrorists are trying to kill him, and the spies are trying to stop the terrorists.

name: L' Invasion des Krolls
description:
A magazine game from Jeux et Stratégie #47

The Krolls are invading Earth. In 30 days, players must find them out, capture them and seize their secret weapon.

Designer of the game : Dominique Tellier

name: Madeline and the Gypsies
description:
From the Young Reader's series of games, produced by Ravensburg.

Where is Madeline? Where is Pepito? They are in the Gypsy Circus, can you find them?

The box and the author's website list this game as 3 to 6 players ages 4 and up, but the instructions a variant for 2 to 4 players. In both variations the object is to find Madeline and Pepito and get rid of all your tiles.

It is a simple game that does not require reading skills of the players.

name: Go Round
description:
Be the first player who places all 13 counters. The spaces on the board are surrounded by more spaces. The spaces in the middle is the area where counters are placed. On the outer spaces each player places a pawn. That pawn moves by rolling a dice. And determines where a counter is allowed to be placed.
Graphics by Doris Matthaeus

name: Versuch dein Glück
description: Place stones and win whenever you earned 40 points.

name: Beletage
description: Whoever get rid off their chips first wins the game. Roll the dice. Place one chip on the gameboard. For every dice with the same number as on the gameboard, place one more chip.
publishers: Spiel & Autor, W. Nostheide Verlag GmbH

name: Battle of the Coral Sea
description: Japanese wargame on the Battle of the Coral Sea. Published by Tsukuda hobbies.

name: Im Reich der Lotosblumen
description: The game is over when all spaces of the gameboard are occupied. The player with most influence gets points. The player with the most points wins.

name: U.S.A. Trivia
description: U.S.A. Trivia is a straight-up trivia game featuring United States geography, history and government. Players move on a path looping through the 50 states, beginning in Maine and ending in Hawaii. The color of the state the pawn is resting on determines the color used on the card. Successful answers allow a die roll and another turn, unsuccessful answers pass control.
publishers: Boynton Games, The Games Gang, LTD

name: The Grid
description:
From the publisher:

The Grid is a board game, officially licensed by the Federation of American Football Leagues (FAFL). It simulates the excitement of Yankee Rules football, as players take control of their favorite teams and players. Each of the twelve teams in the 2050 FAFL World Tournament is represented by its complete 15-man roster. Play out your own tournament, and see if you have what it takes to coach your team to the championship!
categories: Card Game, Dice, Science Fiction, Sports

name: Fast Word
description:
Fast Word is a card game where you create and swap words based on the throw of the die. With the simple goal of creating and keeping as many words as possible, other players try to take your words off the table and even right out of your hand! The winner is the player who has the most points from creating words in his/her possession when the game ends.

Contents:
92 Letter Cards
12 Wild Cards
1 Playing Die
6 Die Instruction Cards
mechanics: Pattern Building, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: The Mileage Game
description: In The Mileage Game, players compete in trying to travel the greatest number of miles using the least number of gas tokens. The game ends when one player has traveled 2000 miles; however, the winner is the player who has achieved the best Miles Per Gallon (MPG) score.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: 1869: The Golden Spike
description:
This is a game in the 18xx system, set in the Western United States, and dealing with the building of the first transcontinental railroad and its aftermath. It has many special features:

1. Bonds to encourage the first transcontinental railroads to build track along historical routes.
2. Land grants to add extra income.
3. Connection bonuses.
4. Special city tiles that add extra length to trains that run through a token there.
5. Refurbished trains.
6. Palace cars (trains that double the value of one city run through with another train)
7. Mergers (some forced, some optional)

Overall, an interesting attempt, but the bonds seem quite out of balance, so that victory in the game seems determined by who owns the most Union Pacific and Central Pacific shares after the first stock round.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Network and Route Building, Stock Holding, Tile Placement

name: Can You Make It as a Backpacker?
description:
Can you make it as a BACKPACKER? That's the challenge of a new adventure-filled board game that tells you if you’ve got what it takes to travel the world.

Do the Visa Run, find your accommodation, and then hit the bar but keep an eye on your bag! Discover the must-do traveling experiences and the pitfalls to avoid, see the sights and survive the rickety public transport - all whilst racing across six continents with your mates. The first to travel the world in one piece wins the game

Just like the real thing, you have to travel on a tight budget - but don’t worry, there are plenty of opportunities to work and even phone home to bag some extra cash from Mum and Dad! You'll realize how quickly your money runs out, learn about the scams, the transport, the toilets... It's as close as you can get to the real thing without the food poisoning.

Designed by Marcus Lane, an experienced traveler, the game offers a backpacking insight that is difficult to grasp from books alone. Marcus says, “When I was knocking back a home-made rocket fuel in a remote Asian village one day I realized what a fascinating yet surreal world I was traveling in. I had read books that touched on some of the real issues of backpacking but nothing came close to telling me the full story. I decided to find another way to teach people what they were in for. It's as close to a trial run as there can be. You'll see how challenging yet fun the experience can be as you travel around the world meeting lots of new people and consuming all sorts of strange foods.”

Can you make it as a BACKPACKER? is quite simply the fun way to learn how to plan a safe trip.

Great for gap year students, career break gappers or anyone who fancies a trip down memory lane. Contains a gameboard, 6 backpackers, 224 Visa Run cards, 156 Continent cards, a Foreign Embassy, a wedge of doofers (cash), a dice and rules.

No cockroaches included!

name: My First Dinosaur Dash
description: A dinosaur race for preschool children. Helps young children learn about dinosaurs and develop their word and number skills.

name: Mythmatical Battles
description:
From the Company's Web Site:

Mythmatical Battles is a dueling card game for two players or two teams. It blends mythology and multiplication to create an innovative game which lets kids drill multiplication while engaging in epic mythological battles. For the first time education is infused into the wildly popular dueling/ collecting card phenomenon. Welcome to a FRESH TWIST ON FLASHCARDS with this fun new MULTIPLICATION GAME!
Each player uses his own Mythmatical Battles Deck, with 55 cards featuring gods, heroes, and monsters from Greek, Celtic, Norse, or Egyptian mythology. Every card has one multiplication equation for its attack strength and one equation for it's defense strength. A single deck contains all the multiplication equations from 1x1 to 9x9.

The players take turns drawing cards from their decks, placing them face-up to the "Field" (known to grown-ups as the table, desk, or floor), and challenging their opponent's cards. The card with the highest product wins. But look out --Magic and Weapon cards can change card strengths, and weaker cards can team up to conquer a powerful card.

Each defeated opponent's card goes into the player's "Plunder" pile. The game ends when one player's deck is exhausted. The player with the most cards in her "Plunder" pile when the game ends, wins.

A full deck game takes 45 minutes to play. Or you can play time limit games to fit into a busy class or home schedule. To win a time limit game the person with the most cards in his "Plunder" pile when time's up wins.

Mythmatical Battles is designed for kids in the 3rd to 6th grade. Any kid (and there are millions) who's played with other dueling cards will easily catch on to the rules of Mythmatical Battles, plus learn classic mythology and rock solid math.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Educational, Math, Mythology

name: Fang mich! ... wenn du kannst
description:
This game has nothing in common with the 2004 "Catch Me!".

Translated roughly from Synes Ernst's description on the Spiel des Jahres site:

"Catch me! ... if you can" is an exciting mixture of memory and chasing game. This makes the uncomplicated, shrewd game of Oded Berman a genuine family game, where children have the same chances as adults. The goal of the game is to overtake, and thus remove from the running, the pieces of fellow players. Who remains at the last is the winner. One moves on a round track, formed at the beginning of the game by 24 disks. The speed at which a piece advances is determined by numbers and symbols on the bottom of the disks. One must remember thus where which disk is.

Catch me! ... if you can: In this unique game the board is made up of cards with numbers on one side & a rabbit on the other. After shuffling & arranging these in a circle, rabbit side up, the players rabbits are placed at random & players must remember the position of cards as they are turned over & what is on each. The last remaining rabbit is the winner.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Memory, Racing
publishers: Big Box, Carlit, Otto Maier Verlag, Spear's Games

name: Sodavandsfabrikken
description:
There are lots of different kinds of bottles in the factory: Yellow, red, green, brown, orange and clear. Each player has his own case, where the different bottles are mixed - with exactly 4 of each colour. A handful of bottles are drawn from the bag. If there are fewer than 4 of a kind, they are placed on the transportation track, but if you are lucky and draw exactly 4 of a kind, you may place them in your case immediately. If you get more than 4 of a kind, you will have to return that colour to the bag. The more bottles you draw, the bigger the chance of you geting your case filled, but you also increase the risk of drawing to many.

If you already have bottles on your transportation tracks (from last time you drew), you will add those to the next handful you draw.

name: Feuerwehr
description:
The old part of town is burning! All four fire stations have been alarmed, and the fire-brigade cars are immediately in motion, but unfortunately four vehicles before each fire-brigade car block their way to the house in the center. The fight against the time begins. All players lose if the house is covered with twelve flames; all win if every player's fire-brigade car has reached the house in time.

from http://www.spielarchiv.de/spiel/f/feuerwehr/feuerwehr.htm

name: Rebellion
description: Rebellion is a 2 player card game of strategy, betting, and intrigue. Each player represents the leader of a war-torn nation in the midst of a civil war. The player who manages their resources and outplays their opponent will gain favor of the people and eventually control of the government.

name: Pin
description: A simple abstract solitaire game (players can compete by taking the same setup and trying to outscore the other). 20 pegs ('pins') of five different colors are placed on a square 7x7 board. The game contains two white pins which are connected by a string - the first white pin is placed on the board with the starters. The player's challenge is to place the 2nd white pin on the board, looping the string around as many pins as possible, each color pin being a different value. The string must change direction at each pin, and the 2nd white pin must be placed so that the string is taut. A unique and challenging puzzle for one or two.

name: Rare Species
description:
RARE SPECIES is a 2-4 player memory game endorsed by UK botanist/conservationist David Bellamy.

The game contains a playing board, four conservation park boards, four playing pieces and 24 rare species playing cards. These cards illustrate breeding pairs of 12 of the world's most endangered and rare species of wildlife. The females have cards with pink backs and the males have blue backs.

The 12 female cards are placed face down on 12 yellow squares in the middle of the board. The 12 male cards are placed face up on the 12 green squares that surround the female cards. The playing pieces are placed on the circular brown track, next to one of the corners of the board.

Players take it in turns to roll the dice and move their playing piece in a clockwise direction around the board. Once moved the playing piece will be next to one of the male animal cards. The player attempts to make a pair by turning over one of the female cards and showing it to the other players:
- If it is a match then the piece is removed and placed face down in one of the three bamboo cages at the entrance to that player's conservation park. The male is left in place on the board. Each cage can only hold one female so therefore a player can only collect a maximum of three females without them forming part of a breeding pair.
- If it is not a match then the card is returned to its original face down position.

When a conservationist lands next to the male of any species they may make their play as for the opening rounds if they have no females in their bamboo cages. If, however they have a female or females caged at the entrance to their conservation park, and they think that one of them is the mate of the male that they have just landed next to, they may attempt to turn that female face up:
- If they are correct they remove the male from the playing board and place it with the female face down in the conservation park (not back in the cage). This breeding pair takes no further part in the game
- If they choose the wrong female then it is simply turned face down again on the conservation park board.

Unscrupulous conservationists may also "steal" breeding females from other player's conservation parks. When a player lands alongside a male and they think that one of the other players has its mate in one of their cages then they can attempt to steal it by turning it over:
- If they are correct then the piece is "stolen" and moved to one of their own cages.
- If they are wrong, it is returned face down where it came from, and if the erring player has any females in his own cages then one of them is released back to one of the free yellow squares in the middle of the board.

No more than one conservationist can occupy the same space on the outside track, and spaces that are not next to males (i.e. the male has already been claimed) are not counted for movement purposes.

At the end of the game, when all the females have been paired, the player with the greatest number of breeding pairs in their conservation park is the winner.
mechanics: Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Keep On Truckin' America
description:
Players complete trips across the united states as truckers. The game includes an oversized gameboard, money, various types of special cards (Dispatch Cards, Smokey Sez! Cards, Bonus Cards, Truck Scales Cards, Keep On Truckin' Cafe Cards, and Time Cards), and small plastic trucks.

The game begins by rolling for a dispatch card. Then players roll the die and move along their assigned route (from the dispatch card). Many spaces require that a user draw a card and follow the directions. Once a player finishes five trips he wins.

The game is an attempt to present a realistic trucking experience. For instance (quote from the rules): "If a trucker cannot pay a debt or loses all of his money, he is bankrupt. Going bankrupt is one of the realities of trucking. The player cannot borrow money. He cannot continue to play."

name: Moriarty
description: To win the game, you must score the most points over your opponent. This is done by cleverly moving pieces on a gameboard in order to gain the best advantage. Also, if you can deduce what color your opponent has selected, you will score ALL points on the board.

name: Reflexion
description:
Two players each have a board with a mirror at one side and two two-sided pieces with a red and yellow pattern on them. Each round, one of the cards is turned face up, showing a pattern that can be made with the two pieces and their image in the mirror.

Simultaneously, both players try to create the pattern on the card with their two pieces. The first player who manages this gets the card, which counts as a victory point. When the deck is exhausted, the player with the most cards wins.

For solitaire play, the rule book includes extra patterns using all four pieces.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement
publishers: Jigsaw Toy Factory, Otto Maier Verlag

name: Bats in Your Belfry
description:
OBJECT: to collect the most bats by catching them in the included 'MONSTER CLAWS'.

This game does not have a game board per-se - it utilizes a 3-D supposedly haunted dwelling resembling a castle or mansion for gameplay. The model measures about 35cm high x 20cm across x 15cm deep.

The small black plastic vampire bats are placed on a spring-loaded platform at the top of the model. The players select one of the two garishly colored neon plastic Monster Claws each.

Marbles are inserted into the top of the dwelling and roll through passages within the interior of the model. The route of the marbles can be manipulated by using the 'Skunker Skulls' - little green skulls which are located at the base of the castle. The marbles may roll completely through the model (there are instructions, such as "Take Another Turn" where these terminate) or they may activate the spring-loaded platform where the plastic vampire bats have been placed. The bats are propelled into the air and must be caught in one's Monster Claw.

name: Dragons
description:
The best way to describe this game is: get D&D, Blue Max, and Mechwarrior, and mix them up.

Each player has one or more dragons with different stats, riders, spells, objects and so on.

Every turn the players choose their movement (simultaneously and secretly) then roll for initiative, move the dragons, spit some fire.

In the box there are rules, character sheets, dice, hex maps and counters.
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Role Playing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Altar
description:
(Description from the box)

The game of strategy and wit for two players involving thirteen geometric elements and an invisible force.

The geometric shape of the individual playing pieces indicates how they may be moved, while maintaining a simple visual and tactile quality.

The invisible force relies on the imagination of the players. The concept is similar to the repelling forces between two magnets. In the game 'Altar' imaginary repelling forces exist between the different colored playing pieces.

The object of the game is for a player to maneuver the opposing color altar (cube) into the central recess and then to place their own templar (cone) on top of that altar (cube) to win the game.

The three dimensional design of the board incorporates recessed areas. These may only be crossed by the raven (hexagonal shape), which normally requires an obstacle to jump over to complete its move. The other playing pieces may only cross these areas by using an altar piece (cube) as a 'bridge' or 'stepping stone'.

The unique concept which controls and unifies the game enables 'Altar' with relatively few pieces to develop many permutations. Consequently a depth and level comparative to that of 'chess' can evolve with the individual.

name: Sportz Dice: Tennis
description: A dice game that has nothing in common with Tennis except the name and terminology. The game consists of three dice which include one "Serving" dice and two "Rally" dice. The first player rolls the "Serving" dice and if a "Good Serve" is rolled then the 2nd player rolls the "Rally" die trying to roll a "Return" result, whereupon the first player will then roll the "Rally" die. This continues until one player rolls an "out" result. Play continues using standard Tennis scoring rules. Play best out of three or five sets to determine game winner.

name: Pocket Pictures
description: A word game where you sketch a phrase or word chosen from five categories (Famous People, Travel, Sports/leisure, Sights & Sounds, and Food/Drink) and others. Points are awarded to both the sketcher and the player who guessed it correctly. Good travel game fits in one pocket or purse and can be played in the back of a car while traveling.

name: Ballerina Card Game
description:
Five games included using cards showing ballet positions.

The first (and most educational) requires the players to take the position shown on a card and the other players try to guess the name of the position.

Three rummy variants are also included, as well as a memory game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Children's Game, Memory
mechanics: Acting, Memory, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Terratain
description:
An abstract strategy game of unit placement and scoring for 2+ players. The designer has referred to it as Advanced Colour Wars. Each player has a set of tiles (cities, armies, palaces, mines, etc...) and players take turns placing them on the board following certain rules. Once the board is full, scores are calculated based on various patterns. The most points wins!

Rules: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Terra.html

Online Play


Super Duper Games
mechanics: Hand Management, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Connex'Oh
description:
Another case where a black and white design meets a 2 player abstract game.

2 players face each other across a large plastic board that contains 6x6 square plastic tiles. All tiles are divided into a black and white triangular half, with a landing space on each side for the playing piece of that colour. Tiles have a handle stuck in the middle that enables them to be lifted up, twisted round and replaced without the risk of having pieces slip off. Both the black and white player have 6 stones in their respective colours that start on opposite sides of the board. All tiles initially face the same direction, so that no two touching sides have the same colour and hence no "connections" exist on the board at the start of play.

By twisting tiles, players can create "connections" of identically coloured halves, creating a corridor along which pieces of that colour can progress. Each turn players either twist one tile in the aim to improve the available route, or move a stone along one of those routes. Players try to remove all stones in their colour from the other side of the board. The first to do so is the winner. A tile that has just been lifted gets a red marker on it. It prevents that tile from being turned by the player who is next. Additionally, it also prevents 1 or 2 neighbouring tiles from being turned, as long as a connection in that player's colour was created to the neighbouring tile(s) by the newly placed one. An elegant rule that prevents stalemates and adds another tactic to employ.

Sébastien Sjoholm copyrighted this game in 1989, but it wasn't until 1992 before it appeared with EdiGames, that since has published more of his designs. Connex'Oh won several awards ("As d'Or", Cannes Festival International des Jeux 1992; "Médaille d'Argent", Concours Lépine, Paris, 1992; "Médaille d'Or", Salon international des Inventions de Geneve, Geneve, 1993) and has been re-issued in 1995 as Connexo, again with EdiGames, but this time the board was only 4x4.

name: Zetema
description:
Zetema is a Victorian card game that Sid Sackson included in A Gamut of Games.

Zetema is played with a 65-card deck consisting of the standard 52 cards plus an additional two through Ace in one suit. Each player's objective is to reach a certain number of points. These can be scored by discarding assemblies (five cards of same rank from the hand), completing tricks (five cards of same rank on the table), setting up marriages (king and queen of same suit from hand and table combined), or revealing flushes and sequences (six cards of same suit or sequential rank). With four or six players the game is played in two teams.
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Team-Based Game
publishers: (Public Domain), Dover Publications, dtv (Deutscher Taschenbuch Verlag), Hugendubel Verlag, Hutchinson, Random House, Inc., RBA Libros S.A.

name: Stak Attack
description: The object of the game is to remove one block at a time from anywhere in the criss-crossed wooden block stak and place it on top until one player causes the stak to tumble!

name: Barbara Cartland: A Romance Boardgame
description:
What Geek wouldn't want to explore the wonderful worlds of the late Barbara Cartland? In this game, you choose from one of 12 BC heroines. "Whether she is a rich American heiress or a poor peasant girl, you'll recognize her to be a true Barbara Cartland heroine: soft, gentle, innocent, and pure, but also intelligent, charming, and resourceful."
Players then follow the heroine in her adventures on the Mayfair Modular map using a paragraph style Adventure Book. The winner is the first to (presumably) meet her True Love, and reach her Happy Ending. "Sigh..."

name: Christmas-in-a-Box
description:
"It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas! Christmas in-a-Box is a game filled with all the things that make Christmas the best time of year. Buy properties such as Christmas Cookies, Mistletoe, Sleigh Ride, Fruit Cake, or Lump of Coal. Be good or you may be sent to Naughty or end up with a Scrooge Fine! Land on Santa Claus and collect everything in the center of the board! Christmas in-a-Box is sure to bring family and friends together for a jolly good time. Perfect for family get-togethers or holiday gift giving.
Ages 8 and up for 2 to 6 players."

"Christmas-in-a-Box" was also released in 2004 as "'Twas the Night Before Christmas" with a different board, but the game remains the same: a strict Monopoly clone.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Landskamp
description:
Landskamp ("International match"; "Cap") is a simple soccer game, from the 1970's, played on a field of 21 X 28 squares. Every team has 11 players represented by plastic minitures. On your turn you roll a special die that determains how far you may move your players. If you get two numbers you can move two players otherwise you can move just one. The players steal the ball by moving past it. If you end up on the square next to the ball carrier you risk a penalty for roughing. If you complete a pass play you may roll one extra die and move again.

The game is British but seems only to have been available in a Swedish edition. The British name might actually be World Soccer since it is to be found on the side of the lid on the Swedish edition.

It’s very similar with the dutch game https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/312900/goal. Same cover but the difference is that Goal! also uses a regular die with the special die to move the players.

name: Psi Squad
description:
A logic game for three or more players. Object: To end the game with the most status by guessing the keys to the other players cyphers while keeping your cypher's keys as much of a mystery as possible.

It's 2138 AD. You attend an exclusive academy for individuals with psychic talents. For the past two months you've been under consideration for admission to an elite program. Now it's just down to you and a handful of others: The best of the best. If you pass this final test, you'll be sent on an important mission to an outpost outside the solar system!

In this test, you will choose a sequence of four concepts, or 'keys'. This specific sequence of keys is your 'cypher'. You and your fellow applicants will be locked in an isolation chamber. Your mission is to use your telepathic abilities to probe the minds of your rivals to uncover the keys to their cyphers while protecting your own cypher from discovery.

Success means a promotion and adventure. Failure means another 21 sessions of Dr. Quinto's 'Meditation Under Extreme Duress' class.

Do you have what it takes?
http://invisible-city.com/play/104/psi-squad

name: How to Host a Scavenger Hunt: Animal Safari
description:
A party game from the makers of the popular "How To Host A Murder" series. "How to Host A Scavenger Hunt: Animal Safari" combines the zaniness of a road rally, the adventure of a treasure hunt, and the thrill of a race against the clock - ending at the point-totaling post-hunt party.

Components: 1 host's guide, 20 team badges, 4 team paddles, 4 badge card clue lists, 4 official "things" lists, 4 team envelopes with instructions, 1 official scoresheet, 16 postcard invitations, 16 badge cards, 4 "stuff" bags.

name: Wort-schWatz
description: Another quick word game, this has the trick that the letters can be read any which way up. That h could be a y, that Z is an N. Players scramble to get the best words from the cards on the table.

name: Monopoly: Desi
description:
Monopoly Desi is the Indianised version of regular Monopoly. Players get to travel from Broadway in Southall, to the city’s Nehru Centre, stopping en route at Kiribati - all places associated with the Asian community in the UK.

Cutting a wider migratory map, the other important halts in the game’s four main travel squares include several Indian destinations such as New Delhi Station, Shivaji Chattrapati Station in Mumbai, Chennai’s Central Station and the Howrah station in Kolkata. Some of these zones even carry adverts on the expatriate tribe, Pataks curry pastes, Asian NGOs and, even one for an Indian cable TV.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Criminal Tango
description:
SIX detectives hunting the bandits in the city of "BELLA BALERNO".... who will capture most of the robbers ?
contents:
1 board map of BELLA BALERNO
27 gangsters
12 clues cards
24 action cards...
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Sizzletoad!
description:
You've just stumbled onto a small secret pond, hidden right in your own neighborhood. Three odd little creatures and their frog-friends are playing, and whatever their game is it's good! There's a duck made of paper, a bug trapped in a rock, and a toad spitting sparks from its tongue.

They're all squealing and jumping, leap-frogging and bumping, and racing the pond; oh what fun! Such tumbling and flapping and sparking and quacking; how you'd love to join the confusion. Then they all see you watching and ask you to play, and assure you it's not an intrusion.

Sizzletoad! is the game for two to four players (ages 5 and up) that combines rock-paper-scissors and tic-tac-toe with an exciting leap-frog race around the pond! There's a nice bluffing element as well (especially in the 2-player version).

Players duel with each other in rock-paper-scissors style using their 12-card hands of Fossilticks, Paperducks, and Sizzletoads to decide which player will be able to put cards on the lily pad pond, make a tic-tac-toe, and score the most victory points.

During the race around the pond the excitement builds as the players speed closer and closer to the flower at the finish-line! Care for a game of Sizzletoad! anyone?

This is a great game for parents to play with their kids when they're looking for a bit more variation and strategy than say, "Candy Land" or the like.

Here's a quick "How to Play" summary for the two-player game:

In a two player game, of Sizzletoad! the players shuffle and split the deck (which is filled with an equal number of Sizzletoads, Fossilticks, and Paperducks.)

Each round a single card is compared between the players and the winner of the duel puts either of those two cards onto the lily-pad tic-tac-toe grid of the board. The other card goes into that player's discard pile.

When one of the players places a matching "3-in-a-row" card on the tic-tac-toe grid, the other player counts the cards in his/her own discard pile, scores one point for each card and moves his/her game piece around the board by that many pips, then hands his/her cards over to the maker of the tic-tac-toe.

The maker of the tic-tac-toe then puts those cards into his/her own discard pile and adds them all up, scoring one point for each card and also moving his/her game piece around the board by that many pips.

All of the cards are then shuffled, re-dealt, and the players have another duel. The players continue dueling and adding cards to the board and their own discard piles and moving their game pieces around the numbered pips on the board.

The winner is the player who makes it all the way around the board onto or past the flowered lily-pad before the other player.

With easy game play, this solid game is a fine addition to any "children's'" game library.

Remember: Sizzletoad-beats-Paperduck-which-beats-Fossiltick-which-beats-Sizzletoad!

Sizzletoad! by Mindspan Labs (previously WizerGames) is Made in the USA

Mindspan Labs Digital has released a 1 and 2 player app version of Sizzletoad! that is now available in the Apple app store.
categories: Animals, Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game

name: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer
description:
In 1948, Parker Brothers indulged in a slight bit of overproduction when it introduced its version of the Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer game. Two to four players compete at this spin-and-move race to the chimney.

There are two editions to this game. One is a standard long-box game with a traditional foldout game board, featuring flat plastic reindeer on wooden stands. The other edition features a 3-D rooftop game board that sits atop the game box, with holes in the roof to insert the plastic reindeer for movement. Both editions include a wooden nose for Rudolph to help a player in moving through the cloud spaces.

The 3-D version also came with a Santa Claus sack of five jingle bells so that players could mark how many times they had won. I do not recall if the standard edition came with this sack.

name: Royal Carpet
description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Object: Be the first player to get two Kings off the far edge of the board. This is done by laying down a carpet of friendly Checkers for the Kings to jump.

Only one piece may be moved or introduced per turn. Checkers may be introduced onto any empty square. Alternatively, Checkers may move to any adjacent, empty square. A King may only move by jumping (in any direction) over friendly Checkers or Kings, capturing as he goes. Captured Checkers may be reintroduced later, but Kings that are captured do not return to the game.

The mechanics of jumping are the same as in the game Checkers, except that Kings may jump off the far edge of the board, into the 'end zone.' This King is removed from play. If a King has an opportunity to jump, he must jump, continuing until no more jumps are possible. So beware!

Winning: Victory is achieved when a player has jumped two Kings into the end zone.

Royal Carpet is an attempt to create a game of tempo in which friendly pieces have both positive and negative synergies. Crafty players will block jumps and then unblock them later, forcing an enemy King to jump his royal brethren. For those so inclined, this game is fun to play with a backgammon doubling cube, held initially by the Red player.

name: Sibling Rivalry
description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

The sibling rivalry between you and your brother is legendary. Some ascribe the antagonism to the circumstances of your birth: When the Queen bore identical twins sons many years ago, a careless midwife placed both infants in the same bassinet without identifying the elder, and the rightful heir to the throne has been in doubt ever since. Others believe that your fierce competitiveness is simply a distillation of the belligerence that runs throughout your bloodline. For whatever reason, you have spent your entire life trying to prove your superiority to your brother.

Unfortunately, that life is about to end.

Four days ago Barbarians attacked from the west. Both you and your brother marshaled your individual forces and followed your father to meet the enemy. At first it seemed the battle would be easily won: for each of your soldiers who fell in battle a score of Marauders were dispatched. But by the third day it became apparent that, while your own forces rapidly dwindled, there would be no end to the Barbarian horde. And this morning your losing battle quickly became a rout: The King was slain, you found yourself surrounded, and the forces controlled by you and your brother were reduced to a mere handful a piece.

Now, as the Marauders press in, you know that you will soon be sent to your reward. But you don't fear death. In fact, only one thing weighs on your mind: this is your absolute last chance to outdo your brother. And you are certain he is thinking the same thing.

Object: Each player will attempt to amass more Kills than his opponent before both Princes die in battle.

Reference cards are also provided but not required.

name: Symbio
description:
IntroductionSymbio is a game where each player's groups of cells, or pieces, attempt to surround each other. It was inspired by the immune system's ability to surround pathogens.

Two players, Black and White, take turns to either place or move one of their pieces adjacent to another of their pieces, on an 8x8 board. In order to make a move, the players' formations of pieces must have an open space adjacent to them. The game ends when one player can no longer make a move.



DefinitionsIn these rules, "adjacent" always means "orthogonally adjacent". A body is an adjacent set of pieces of the same colour. A foreign body is an opponent's body. A body has freedom if at least one of its pieces is adjacent to an empty square.



PlayAt the start of the game, Black pieces are placed on b6, b7, c7, f2, g2 and g3, and White pieces are placed on b3, b2, c2, f7, g7 and g6.

Black plays first, then turns alternate. On their turn, a player must first move one of their bodies and then add a piece to the board adjacent to one of their bodies.

The movement of a body involves taking a piece from the body and moving it to a different square adjacent to the body (including squares adjacent to the piece itself). A body cannot move unless it has freedom.

A body's move may land on a foreign body piece, thus removing it from the board, if that foreign body has no freedom.

A player wins if their opponent cannot add a piece next turn. This will occur if the opponent has either no remaining pieces on the board or no remaining bodies with freedom.



NotesThe movement rules result in a pseudopod-like movement which may split a body into two smaller bodies (meiosis). Conversely, movement may result in two or more bodies coalescing.

Players should strive to surround foreign bodies and eat them away while giving their own bodies as much freedom as possible. Keeping a foreign body surrounded ties up pieces.

It is thought that cycles cannot occur due to the addition of a piece per turn. Neither player can move on a full board, but the player to place the last piece must by definition win the game.

name: Speckles
description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Each player selects a color. Each player in turn (clockwise if more than 2) places one piece of any color, on any vacant square, alongside a differently colored piece or pieces, if any, already in play. The first straight line of four adjacent pieces with a player's color at each end wins for that player.

name: Sproing
description:
SPROING
The Action Game of Unbearable Fun!

AGES: 7 to Adult
OBJECT: Get rid of your cards in hand, but also avoid getting stuck with the discard pile cards when the SPROING tray goes "SPROING!"
EQUIPMENT: 1 Special SPROING pop-up discard tray
54 Numbered Cards consisting of: 32 Blue Cards and 22 Yellow Cards
1 Bag
6 Multi-Colored Plastic Chips

Each player in turn discards a card in the special SPROING tray before it pops up. Yellow action cards add excitement to the game by directing players to roll dice, find color chips in a bag or count out loud before discarding a card.

This curious game relies on a coiled plastic tray that may be pressed down to become held in place by a sucker. The sucker holds the tray down for about 1.5 minutes (according to the makers) before suddenly releasing the tray, allowing it to pop up and scatter all cards that happened to be on it.

Players try to play a card that is either a '1' or a number higher than the top card on the tray. The blue cards are numbered from 1 to 10, with lots more 1s than other numbers. The yellow cards are numbered from 1 to 9, but also have actions described on them that must be performed by the next player. The next player has to complete the actions before they are allowed to play their card. The actions could require players to count (for example, from "Sproing 1" to "Sproing 10"), roll a specific combination on two special dice (each die has 3 blank sides and 3 sides showing a coiled spring), or draw a chip of a specified color from an opaque bag.

Anyone unfortunate enough to have the tray pop up during their turn has to keep all scattered cards, which count as points against the player who owns them. The player with the lowest number of points wins.

name: Kleiner Eisbär, kannst du fischen?
description:
Alternative names:
Plume, sais-tu pecher?
Piuma dimmi sai pescare?

"Little Polar Bear, do you know fishing?" is a memory-like game. Players move little polar bear around a circular track over ice flows. On the back of the flows there are printed fish in 4 different colors. In the middle of the board, there are 16 wooden fish (4 of each color) placed face down. The player has to draw a fish that matches that printed on the floe. Players may decide whether they want to move one, two or three spaces, so memorizing the fish printed on the floes is as important as memorizing those in the center of the board.
publishers: Schmidt Spiele, Selecta Spel en Hobby

name: Big League Baseball Card Game
description: This game comes with 36 cards, instructions, and four score sheets. Each laminated card features black ink line drawings depicting the players, uniforms, and equipment of the era (1949) plus and possible play outcomes, which include home run, triple, double, singles, sacrifice, error, strike outs, walks, stolen base, passed ball, pickoff, and doubleplay.

name: Checkersaurus Rex
description: Checkersaurus Rex is a game kit that contains two different games. The first game is simply Checkers, played with a collection of dinosaurs - with the Tyrannosaurus Rex miniatures used for the kings. The other game is a relatively trivial roll & move with some of the flavor of chutes and ladders combined with some childish goofiness: landing on the "Dino Stomp" square means the player must stand up and stomp about the table; landing on the "Dino Roar" square requires the player to emit a throaty roar; "Dino Food" is probably best not described, for fear of offending the sensitive reader.

name: Wizzword
description:
"The fast moving, quick thinking word game"

"Challenge each other to solve word scrambles. Can you be the first with the solution, hit your button and leave your opponent in a confusion of letters? But be clever, next time he may turn the tables on you!"

A simple anagram solving game with a twist, the board spins 180 degrees at the press of a button.

The main game component is a large and sturdy plastic board with a rotating central section triggered by either of two chunky red buttons in the corner of each side. Also included are two plastic trays containing an assortment of letters in two colors, in my edition (blue on white / white on blue and red on white / white on red). German umlauted versions of A,O and U are also included.

Each player secretly composes a word of up to 10 letters in their home rack on the stationery part of the board, then transposes the word into the upper rack of the yellow turntable. The turntable is then rotated and each player races to place their other colored letters in the middle rack to try to solve the anagram. The first player to solve the anagram presses their red button and presents their answer to their opponent. If correct they win if wrong they lose. The winning player claims the tiles used by the loser at the end of each round. Play continues until a player is unable to solve a word with their available letter tiles.

A good educational game designed to expand your child's vocabulary and improve their mental agility with a tiny amount of strategy in word selection.

The only flaw with the game is the overly enthusiastic rubber band powered mechanism, which when activated, scatters both sets of tiles.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Puzzle, Word Game
publishers: MB Jeux, MB Spellen, MB Spiele, Milton Bradley

name: Win, Lose or Draw Junior
description:
From back of box:
"This simpler Junior version of Win, Lose or Draw is designed for children ages 8 to 11!
To play, kids pick a card, select a word and call out its category -- People, Places or Things! The sketching starts! The guessing begins! It's a race against time.
Correct guesses reward both the Sketcher and the Guesser with chips. Collect enough chips and then guess correctly once more to win!"
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Racing

name: Wheel of Fortune Game Junior Edition
description:
From back of box:
"Now younger players can enjoy all the fun and excitement of the popular TV game show anytime, any place in this fast-action home version developed especially for players age 7 to 12!

In Wheel of Fortune Junior Edition, you and your opponents compete to be the first player to solve the phrase hidden on the Puzzle Board -- a famous expression, title, person or thing. Spin the Wheel and uncover letters to earn money.

If you can avoid going 'Bankrupt' and complete the phrase, you win the round!

After four rounds, the player with the most cash wins the game!"
publishers: Diset S. A., Parker Brothers, Playtoy Industries, Pressman Toy Corp.

name: Time Flies
description: Players race to play cards that show their favorite activities. From eating ice cream to playing catch, the first player to have 12 hours of fun wins the game. For ages 6 and up, the family game is easy to learn.

name: Voyagers
description: Voyagers is a trivia game based on regions of the world. There are five groups of 80 cards each - North America, South America, Africa & Oceania, Asia, and Europe. Each card has three questions on it - for People, Places, and Things. You choose which region to start in. Once you have answered a question in each of the three categories (People, Places, Things), you can move on to another region. Each correct answer allows you to continue your turn. Once you miss, play passes to the player/team to your left. The first player or team to answer each category in all five regions wins. It's listed for ages 10 to adult.

name: Spion
description:
Spion (=Spy) is a 2-player strategy game with an unusual victory condition: you must find two hidden points on the opponents half of the gameboard. These hidden points are secretly marked on a paper copy of the gameboard; a whole pad of copies is included.

The gameboard has 2 halves of 64 hex-fields each and the armies of the 2 players contain 6 defenders, 4 little spies and 2 big spies. The defenders are single colored, while the spies show both colors, because they can be turned over when captured! Defenders cannot leave their half of the board. Spies can move everywhere and they are therefore needed to find the 2 hidden points.

name: Eddie's Eleven
description: Eddie the eagle and a whole flock of his friends (including Richie the Rabbit, Danny Dof, Wendy the Wolf, Alan the Alligator, and Felicity Frog) want to teach you how to sequence your numbers. The first player has to start by playing Eddie who is number 11. The next player can now play a 12 or a 10 of the same color or another Eddie. If you can't play, you have to draw another card. Be the first to get rid of your cards and you win. Simple, right?

name: Wacky Wilderness
description:
This game involves rolling a six-sided die with images on each side. The images include:
a sad face (lose an animal part)
a happy face (take ANY animal part)
Legs (take a leg piece)
Torsos (take a torso piece)
Tails (take a tail piece)
Heads (take a head piece)

The object of the game is to be the first player to build a "wacky" animal consisting of 1 torso, 1 head, 1 tail and 4 legs. The combinations are colorful and amusing.

Box says ages 4+. But this game plays easily with children 2 1/2 and up.

From the manual and box:

"Ever see a ZEBRA-PHANT? Or an ELE-RAFFE? What a laugh! Roll the die, mix and match body parts, and suddenly things get wacky. Imagination and strategy rule.

In a fast-moving game of chance, children learn color and animal recognition as they roll the die and attempt to "build" a critter."

name: Skittle Score-Ball
description: Players use the swinging skittle ball to try and knock their balls into a set of scoring rings. Similar to skeet ball.

name: Snapshot
description: The game comes with thirty cards with various old time pictures. Fifteen cards are spread out and studied. Then the cards are shuffled and three are removed. The players vie to be first to recall the missing pictures.

name: Hoplon 3
description:
Hoplon 3 is the third edition of a fast play set of ancient and medieval miniatures rules using an amended version of the DBx basing system. This allows players with DBx-based armies to play Hoplon with only minimum changes necessary.
Although designed for 15mm miniatures, the system also supports 25/28mm play. Hoplon has been extensively play-tested in clubs and by members of a dedicated Yahoo group, and this testing has led to a number of revisions which have been incorporated into the third edition.

The philosophy behind Hoplon is to provide an easy-to-learn but deep system emphasizing the relative capabilities of different troop types and morale classes, the difficulties of effective command and control and -most of all - the close matching of historical tactics and performance.

In Hoplon, armies are separated into commands, and commands are separated into units. Troops are activated and controlled by means of command points. While single elements can function individually, they do so at a cost when detached from their parent formations, losing their unit's stamina, cohesion bonus, and ability to maneuver in groups. This in turn forces players to deal with the tactical control problems inherent in commanding large bodies of ancient and medieval troops. Sequence of play is by interleaved-Command (both players moving on the same round by order of initiative of their commands) rather than alternating on every round, which makes tactical decision-making all the more interesting.

While it uses a points system and army lists loosely based on the DBM model, Hoplon has taken a fresh approach to game-play which provides a realistic and historically satisfying simulation of ancient and medieval warfare. As a result, most historical battles require little or no tweaking to re-fight making this set a real tool for simulating actual battles.

name: The $128,000 Question Game
description:
Players compete in a test of knowledge, trying to win the most money by answering questions in the category of their choice.

Based on the TV game show of the same name, hosted by Mike Darrow (pictured on box) for its first season (1976-77).
categories: Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: LEGO Dominos
description:
Match the Colors and Stack Away!

Build your way across the board with LEGO® Dominos – the first color-based Dominos game! Players match and stack their dominos based on color, choosing to zig zag their way to the finish line or block an opponent.

It's great fun for kids to learn colors and practice fine motor skills and fun for adults too!

Contains 56 LEGO bricks, 28 LEGO plates, game board and instructions.

name: Kribbel-Krabbel
description:
A social game for 2-4 players ages six and up.

Players are given like numbers of plastic beetles to hide in illustrated match boxes. In turn, the players roll a die and either attempt to recall the location of an empty match box in which they may hide some beetles or interacting with two personalities who sometimes hide in the match boxes away from beetles. The first player to hide all their beetles wins the game. Remembering wrong about the boxes causes a player to take more beetles -- pushing them further from the win.

name: The Con Game
description:
The Con Game is designed to be played throughout a game convention. Each player has ten cards with a symbol (rock, paper, or scissors) and a number (1 through 10). When encountering another player, the two players can fight or trade. If fighting, a traditional game of Rock, Paper, Scissors using the cards, with ties being null outcomes. Either player can decline a subsequent fight. If trading, each player can reveal as much or as little information as desired, but must be truthful, before making a trade. There are no limits on the number of trades allowed. At the end of the convention, the player with the greatest numerical value of cards wins.

The Con Game was originally designed for JohnCon 2000 and was printed on the convention t-shirt. It is included in Chief Herman's Holiday Fun Pack.

name: Up Against Time
description:
A steel ball is set moving down a ramp towards the base, on which a tower of barrels must be built. Each barrel has a protruding shape on top and a different indented shape on the bottom, to allow some combinations of barrels to interlock. Players must find the correct barrels as quickly as possible and stack as many as they can before the ball arrives. When they have completed as much of the tower as they are able, they shut a gate to stop the ball from reaching the barrels. If they are too slow, the whole tower will fall over when hit by the ball. Players take it in turns to see how high a tower they can build.

Players may use one hand only to stack the barrels. Points are awarded for barrels left standing after shutting the gate and a game comprises three rounds.

The game is called 'Up Against Time!' on the box and 'Up! Against Time' in the rules and on the game itself.

Similar to:

Wallamoppi

name: Transfer
description:
Transfer is a simple abstract 2-player game that is played on a 4x4 grid. Each player starts with 4 egg-cups, in one of two colors, on the base row of the grid, with a ball on the two corner ones. The aim is to be the first player to move these cups to the baseline of the opponent and get the 2 balls again onto the 2 egg-cups on the edges. If the starting player does this first, then the opponent has the chance to get a draw if they manage to do the same thing in the turn immediately afterwards.

Each turn a player picks one of two moves. A player can either move one cup with a ball to a free space that touches it, horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. Or a player can move the ball from one of their pieces to another one of their pieces that touches it in those same directions. When a blockade occurs, by 2 rows that block each other on the center rows, the active player may jump with a piece that contains a ball over an opponent's piece. When one player still has a piece on the start line, and the opponent has filled all other end-spaces, that piece needs to vacate its space right away. If this is impossible (when it doesn't contain a ball), then that player loses immediately.

This appears to be Dieter Hartmann's only published game.

PUBLICATION HISTORY:

1978 Transfer Edition Perlhuhn (Göttinger Spiele) - out of print


Like all typical Edition Perlhuhn releases, this game comes in a tube, with chunky wooden pieces (black and red) and a board that is printed on a fake leather vinyl.

ADDITIONAL INFO:

language skill needed: language neutral.
English translation: none. The description above should suffice.
artwork: no artwork on the board (grid only). The label image appears to be a replication from an old scientific print.
awards won: none.

name: Gridlock
description:
From the press release:

This double-sided board game offers two games in one. In Gridlock Jr. Ages 5-10, players battle a huge traffic jam, directing traffic to get the police car to the crime scene and others where they need to be. Gridlock Sr. Ages 10 and up is more challenging, with vehicle breakdowns, time pressure, and no stop signs. “The special quality of this board game is that it is cooperative. All the players must work together to free up the traffic jam; otherwise, nobody will get anywhere. Sort of like real life!”

name: Shooters
description:
"Shake, Rattle & Score Game
Nine cubes... five have a bead inside--but which ones? Take turns as you each try to pick just the ones with a bead. The more you risk, the more you score--so will you quit after one... or two.. or push your luck and Shoot the Moon?"

A small portable game, consisting of 9 dice within a plastic frame (which keeps them together).
Each dice has one side marked with a color. The one black has a bead inside and one each of the other colored die pairs.
Score based on the number of dice you can select that have beads inside. A push-your-luck mechanic ensures you score 0 if you select wrong.

name: Goal!
description: "Enjoy the thrills and skills of football by planning the moves that bring the goals." A very abstract two player simulation of a football match, published sometime in the late Sixties.

name: Monopoly: Gloucestershire
description: The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Gloucestershire, in the United Kingdom.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Galactic Attack
description:
Bagged game. From the bag cover:
"You are the Commander of the United States Space Forces Galactic Fleet. Recent intelligence reports state that the enemy have deployed an armada in a nearby solar system. Your mission is to push back the advancing fleets and repel the enemy forces."

A low-complexity game of ship-to-ship combat and planet occupation between identical forces approaching each other from opposite ends of a map representing a star system. The map has a square grid superimposed, and movement is orthogonal. On a turn, a player rolls two dice and may make as many moves with any number of ships as he wishes, up to the total value of the two dice, but not to exceed the value of one of the dice in the movement of any, single ship. Unit types are troopers, fighters, transports, and mines. Fighters automatically eliminate troop ships; fighter vs. fighter is determined by high roller. Troops are carried by troopships, and may be dropped on planets; combat on planets is resolved as with fighters.

Two sheets combine to form a 22"x16" mapboard. 121 thin counters are perforated for separation. Two dice are also included. A limited set of advanced rules are also provided.

name: Transformers Skirmish
description:
This is a board/card game for 2 players.
One player is the Autobots and the other one is the Decepticons.
Transformers is a trademark logo and this is a merely fan project, created for fun.
Available for free download (http://www.webalice.it/alecrespi/html/warpspawn.html) or in the files section.
To win you have to defeat all the enemy transformers.
To play you need a 8x8 square board and the appended cardset.
Movements, attacks and defences are all card-driven.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Miniatures, Print & Play
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Point to Point Movement

name: The Three Little Kittens
description: A Simple spin and move game for children, where each player tries to move his kittens around the track and back into the home area. Based on the nursery rhyme of the same name.

name: Sim Wiocha
description:
Polish non-collectible card game originally printed in Portal magazine (issue 4/2000). The aim of the game is to build the best village while disturbing other administrator's efforts. Cards concern issues such as bureaucracy, religious fundamentalism, provincional mentality and socialist heritage.

Available as public domain since 2006.

name: Le jeu du loup
description:
From the back of the box: ``Quick, quick! ... In order to win you must gather all your items before the wolf has all its clothes on. The players take turn drawing from the bag, but be careful, if the wolf's head appears, you have to put an item of clothing on him! This fun game is suitable for players of 3 years and over because there are three versions of the game: all together, one against another or alone... But always against the Wolf.

The game comes with a board representing a forest, onto which six different kinds of items are spread: mushrooms, strawberries, snails, blackberries, flowers and butterflies. In addition, each player receives one leaf-shaped individual board that is uniformly green on one side (for using in cooperative mode), and covered with the shapes of five of the six items on the other side (used in competitive and individual modes). The wolf is drawn on a magnetic board and its five items of clothing (shoes, trousers, jacket, hat and umbrella) are magnetic too. In the bag, eight cardboard discs represent each of the six items that can be picked from the forest, plus the head of the wolf and a clover leaf.

The players draw in turn one disc from the bag. If the wolf's head is drawn, they put an item of clothing onto the wolf. If it is the clover leaf, they can take one item of clothing off the wolf or choose one item of their choice from the forest (competitive and individual mode) or two items from the forest (cooperative mode). Otherwise, they take the item represented on the disc from the forest. The disc is then put back in the bag and passed to the next player.

In competitive mode, the winner is the first player who manages to pick up all the items represented on his board. In cooperative mode, the players win if they manage to empty the forest before the wolf is fully clothed. In individual mode, the player wins if he manages to pick up all the items represented on his board. The game is lost in any mode if the wolf gets all its clothes on.

name: Cookie Jar
description:
From the publisher's web site:

Cookie Jar is an accusations and alibis dice game. Everyone is a suspect, but only one person is the guilt party. Cookie Jar is a mixture of strategy and roleplaying. Each player needs bring fifteen 6-sided dice to the game (and to avoid confusion they should all be the same color, but different from the other players). Suitable for all ages, each session of Cookie Jar last no longer than 30-minutes.

name: 1644: Rules for Battles of the English Civil War (Second Edition)
description: Rules for English Civil War wargames with army lists and campaign system. 2nd Edition is revised and amended.
categories: Civil War, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Monopoly: Mountaineering
description: This Monopoly edition takes you on a mountaineering adventure. Tents and basecamps take the place of houses and hotels, and the pewter tokens are climber, yak, canteen, hiking boot, rope, and tent.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Hasbro, National Geographic Society, Parker Brothers

name: Monopoly: Sunterra
description: This is a version of the Monopoly game based on the theme of vacation resorts, including the Sunterra resort. Players can buy, own, and trade some well known resort properties. Traditional houses and hotels are renamed Units and Resorts, and customized Sunterra themed SunOptions and Exchanges cards replace Chance and Community Chest cards. Includes 6 custom Pewter Tokens which include: Sunterra Flip Flops, Beach Chair, Golf Cart, Beach Cruiser, Jet, and Ski goggles.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Banana Republic
description:
"Can you achieve high inflation, huge unemployment, gigantic debt, and lead the country to the brink of disaster? Great! You're Top Banana!"
In Banana Republic, players attempt to outdo each other in controlling banana republics. The object is twofold: 1. to create the worst governed nation, and 2. become the richest player (in bananas!).
The entire game is themed around everything related to bananas. Players moving around the banana-shaped board may take "banana chance" cards (gaining or losing bananas), answer banana-related trivia questions, choose 'Economy Cards' and bet bananas on their chance of having the worst economic performance in a chosen area (such as inflation, unemployment, etc), bet bananas on having the worst banana republican leader (eg worst Treasurer, worst General) by allotted scores (in order to collect a set of government cards), land on a 5-banana "Bananza", lose bananas in the banana bank, and withdraw other players' bananas from the bank.
The winner (Top Banana) is the player who banana bankrupts all other players.

NB: Although the playing time is stated as 10 minutes, it can often last several hours.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading, Variable Player Powers

name: The Record Game
description:
From the Box:

The RECORD GAME is THE board game that offers you a behind-the-scenes look at the excitement and glitter of the record and music business.

With your first move, you enter the fast-paced world of the entertainment industry. You've got $4 million and it's up to you to make your record a hit.

The RECORD GAME takes you into the recording studio... on the road with your act... into the record stores and radio stations. You must plan promotions, budget your money and carefully manage your sales and inventory. Enjoy the entertainment world but remember that it's good business sense that produces profits, and it's profit that makes a winner in THE RECORD GAME.

The game was endorsed by Kenny Rogers.

Unique Features:


3 variations of play, allowing participants to enjoy a 2-hour, a 5-hour or the demanding 8 1/2-hour excursion into the world of music and records.
a 33 1/3 RPM record containing the basic rules and objectives and the RECORD GAME song.
Dial-A-Square. Call the "Dial-A-Square" number for the square of the day (no longer working, I imagine).
Do-It-Yourself square


Components:


Board - Over 2 feet by 2 feet, showing the spiraling road to number 1 in the center.
Play Money
Dice
Pawns
Crayons
Wipe-off Inventory sheets/radio tracking sheets
Playable Record with the instructions
Several types of cards that determine different aspects of the entertainment industry (Concerts, Radio shows, Inventory, etc.)
Ownership Cards for Music Publishers/Marketing Agencies
Instructions
categories: Economic, Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Muffin
description:
Muffin the Mule was a children's television program made by the BBC through the late '40s and the '50s. This game displays characters and events from the television show.

The game is basically "Strip Jack Naked" or "Beggar My Neighbour" with players playing the top card from their deck to a pile in the centre of the table. If a numbered card is played then the next player must pay cards in succession equal to the number on the card. If while paying out that player turns over a numbered card then the next player must now pay for that card. If a player pays cards to match the required number without revealing a numbered card themselves the player who player the numbered card collects the entire stack from the centre of the table and adds it to the bottom of their own pile.

This game has the addition of 2 Peregrine the Penguin cards. When one of these is revealed the first player to shout "Muffin" instantly wins the centre pile.

Play continues until one player has all of the cards.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Thimk
description:
A snakes and ladders type game for two to four players with some extra strategic manouvres possible including piggy-backing, multiple-piece options and blocking other players.

Each player must move his 4 pieces (thims) up the board by rolling the dice or piggy-backing on the thim of another player. The goal of the game is to have each of your thims on the last four squares of the board. The player can use the blue arrows to advance up the board if he lands on one and if he lands on a square with a red arrow must slide to the bottom of the arrow. There are some special squares that force the player to roll a six to move past that square and some that allow the player to roll the dice again. The most interesting square on the board is the STYMIE square. If a person gets his thim to land on the STYMIE square no other player may move their thims past him until he moves his thim. This makes for a burst for the finish ending in many games. Players may move any of their thims on their turn including ones that may be buried in a stack of other thims as long as they take all thims resting on top of theirs. This rule does not apply on the top row where only the top thim may move.

This is a fairly simple game and probably appeals mostly to children. However there are usually four options for the player on every turn and the race for the finish is usually close.

name: Timestalk
description:
From the rulebook:

"TIMESTALK is a board game for 4 to 6 players, Ages 14 and up. Approximate playing time is 1 1/2 to 2 hours.
TIMESTALK is a race game (the first player to advance through the "four ages", achieve a successful launch, past the Black Hole and directly into the "arrow of outer space" wins the game), but the race is HUMAN and so the path to success is long and arduous, marked by crises, aggressions, precautions and risk-taking.
Interface all of this with the unpredictable consequences of Timewarps and a Black Hole and you have "A SPACE AGE GAME FOR HUNTERS AND GATHERERS".
mechanics: Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Autodrome F1 World Championship
description: A simple sport game that recreates some contests of the championship of the world of Formula 1. The movement of the cars on the circuits is given from the launch of 3 dice, if the result of a launch is equivalent to three equal numbers is the risk of some incident or mechanical problem to the car. In the game are comprised 4 circuits (Monza , Watkins Glen, Monaco and Jarama) and play-money in order to pay the prizes to the winner.

name: ToTem
description:
The game is played on a grid of 9 x 9 squares, each with one of 4 signs (cross, circle, square, triangle) in one of four colours (purple, green, yellow, blue) on it. The 8 pieces are called "totems": statues consisting of four stacked cubes, each separately pivotable, and a sculptured head on top of them. On the four cubes you find the same symbols and colours as on the field.
Each totem can move on the field with the same sign AND colour like the corresponding cube of his pole (the side facing the player!) as follows: If you want to move one space, your lowest cube must correspond to the space one step away, etc., the topmost to the space four steps away. At every turn each player may either move one of his totems as many spaces as the correct cube corresponds to the target field (he can change directions during his move as often as he wishes) or turn one of the cubes of one of his totems and thus prepare for future moves. There is no capturing.
The aim of the game is to move first one of your totems from your starting row to the marked "totem space" on the opposite side (2-player version) or on one of three totem spaces on the sides not being your starting row. In the 2-player game, each player owns 4 Totems, in the 4-player variant 2 of them.
To foresee their opponents` next moves, players have to remember the possibilities of the other totems - more easily done, because before the first move, each player puts the cubes of the opposing Totem into the positions he wants to.
There is a bluff element, too, as only the player moving knows, whether his move is correct or not. If another player doubts the correctness, he may call "Totem!" and the move is checked. If it was not correct, the challenging player can put all the totems of the disproved player on adjacent spaces of his choice. If the move was correct, the same happens the other way round.

The game is part of the Series: Cirkle, consisting of corresponding games, all with the same symbols and colours.

name: Star Hopper
description:
In this space-themed race game, you control 4 spaceships which you send out into the galaxy. At random intervals, your home government approves colonization of various star systems, and the first starship there gets exclusive rights to colonize. The first player with 4 colonies wins the game.

The star card deck show rough graphic representations and the actual names of the 40 closest star systems to our own, the next furthest out that we know or suspect might have planets, and other stars yet further out known for their place in constellations. The rule book gives more details about each of the 107 star systems and general facts about astronomy and astrophysics.

Contains: 1 game board, 108 card deck, 6 six-colored six-sided dice, 24 colored spaceship pawns, 48 translucent colony marker chips, rule book

name: Business India
description:
The follwing has been taken directly from the box (spelling errors have been preserved):

Business India A Trade Game

A game of Buying and Selling Banking Mortaging etc.
Expand your BUSINESS with Tranportation
PROVE YOURSELF AS A RICHER OF ALL

From the Rulebook (written in English and Hindi):

The object of the game is to learn business or trade buying, and selling of properties so that one becomes the wealthiest player by same method and honoured as BUSINESS. Player come across the game ups and down falls sometimes he gets reward and some times he has to pay penalties etc. By arriving at CHANCE OR COMMUNITY CHEST. Right from beginning of the game till the end, it gives to the players excitement, pleasure and ammusement. When a player taken and on a space not already owned, he may buy it from the Bank, otherwise he has to pay rent to the owner of that site, Rents are greatly increased by erection of house and hotels. During Financial difficulties, properties can be mortgaged to the Bank.

Business India is very similar to Monopoly.
mechanics: Ownership, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading

name: Age of Battles: 1242 – Battle of Lake Peipus
description:
Minis-based game using a generous selection of 1/72 miniatures, provided, depicting the fierce battle that transpired between Russian and Livonian knights on the ice of Lake Peipus in 1242, in Estonia. Comes with 72 very high quality plastic soldiers, rules of play, several play aids and a few cardboard tents that need to be cut out and assembled. Packaging is in Russian and English but the game is available with rules in German, French, Spanish, Italian and Dutch.

This game is one of four in the Age of Battles medieval series.

name: Strive For Five: Old Testament
description:
From the box:

Strive For Five is a competitive educational game that is fun for the whole family.

Each card starts with a true or false question. The correct answer will win you the right to play the card. Each youth and pre-school card has 5 multiple choice questions (per side). Each Adult card has 5 questions (per side) with an alphabetical clue to the answer. Can be played with or without the clue.

You must "Strive For Five" correct answers because the person who answers the 5th question, wins the card. If the turn is passed to you on the 5th question, you could win the card with only one correct answer, keeping the excitement level high.

Youth, pre-school, adult and expert cards can be played in the same game for family play.

name: Colorful Clues
description:
4 small pyramids are missing and the players must find which ones they are by using what little information they have (each player starts the game knowing the identity of one of them) and guessing the colors of the remaining ones. But these are hidden randomly under the medium and large pyramids.

A color deduction game for the Icehouse game system.

name: Cthulhu Boardgame
description:
"In 1924 middle England at the residence of an esteemed occult collector, a Mr John Wilson, a murder was discovered. John had been in the middle of a dinner party with some good friends when his wife screamed from the garden. Tabitha Wilson had been taking a walk for some after dinner air when she came across the remains of the gardener. The poor man had been decapitated and eviscerated on the lawn.

"The Police were called to the scene and the investigation begun. Yet more horror was to come. A strange rustling noise came from the hedges at the end of the garden and it drew everyone's eyes. In a sudden rush men burst through the greenery each wielding a knife and screaming for blood.
